This is another of Allah's beautiful names. 'Wa huwa al-'aliyyu al-'aẓīm' = 'And He is the Most High, the Most Great'. The verse concludes with these two perfect names, summarizing everything: He is the HIGHEST (al-'Aliyy) and the GREATEST (al-'Aẓīm). After describing His attributes, power, and knowledge, it ends with His perfection. This is Ayat al-Kursi - the greatest verse of the greatest book!

verses.arabic: لَآ إِكْرَاهَ فِى ٱلدِّينِ ۖ قَد تَّبَيَّنَ ٱلرُّشْدُ مِنَ ٱلْغَىِّ ۚ فَمَن يَكْفُرْ بِٱلطَّـٰغُوتِ وَيُؤْمِنۢ بِٱللَّهِ فَقَدِ ٱسْتَمْسَكَ بِٱلْعُرْوَةِ ٱلْوُثْقَىٰ لَا ٱنفِصَامَ لَهَا ۗ وَٱللَّهُ سَمِيعٌ عَلِيمٌۭ
verses.transliteration: Lā ikrāha fī-d-dīni qad tabayyana-r-rushdu mina-l-ghayyi fa-man yakfur bi-ṭ-ṭāghūti wa yu'min bi-llāhi fa-qadi-stamsaka bi-l-'urwati-l-wuthqā lā-nfiṣāma lahā wa-llāhu samī'un 'alīm
verses.translation: There shall be no compulsion in [acceptance of] the religion. The right course has become distinct from the wrong. So whoever disbelieves in Taghut and believes in Allah has grasped the most trustworthy handhold with no break in it. And Allah is Hearing and Knowing.

grammar.type: Harf - Negation Particle (lā of negation of genus)
grammar.reason: Negates completely what follows - there is absolutely no compulsion.
grammar.practical: This 'lā' is the strongest form of negation! It completely denies the existence of compulsion in religion. This verse establishes one of Islam's fundamental principles: freedom of choice in faith. The 'lā' is emphatic - not 'little compulsion' but ZERO compulsion. Faith must come from the heart voluntarily, not by force!

grammar.root: ك-ر-ه (k-r-h) - to hate, to compel, to force
grammar.reason: What is negated. After this type of 'lā', the noun takes accusative.
grammar.practical: From k-r-h meaning to compel or hate. 'Ikrāh' is the verbal noun: 'compulsion, coercion, forcing'. The 'a' ending is from 'lā'. So 'lā ikrāha' = 'no compulsion' or 'there is no forcing'. This is powerful! You cannot force someone to accept Islam. Real faith comes from understanding and conviction, not threats or pressure. This verse protects religious freedom!

grammar.reason: Shows WHERE there is no compulsion - in religion.
grammar.practical: 'Fī' = 'in'. Specifies the realm: 'lā ikrāha FĪ...' = 'no compulsion IN...' In what? Coming next!

grammar.root: د-ي-ن (d-y-n) - religion, way of life, judgment
grammar.reason: After preposition 'fī'. Specifies the sphere - religion.
grammar.practical: From d-y-n meaning religion, faith, or way of life. 'Dīn' is comprehensive - not just rituals, but the entire way of life. The kasrah (i) is from 'fī'. Complete phrase: 'lā ikrāha fī-d-dīn' = 'There is no compulsion in religion.' One of the most important verses for religious tolerance and freedom! You can explain Islam, show its beauty, but you cannot force anyone to accept it.

grammar.function: Emphasizes the completion or certainty of the verb
grammar.reason: Stresses that the distinction has already become clear.
grammar.practical: 'Qad' is an emphasizing particle meaning 'indeed', 'certainly', or 'has already'. With past tense verbs, it emphasizes completion. With present tense, it adds emphasis. Here it stresses: this has DEFINITELY happened, the distinction is CLEARLY made. 'Qad' adds certainty!

words.translation: it has become clear / it has been distinguished

grammar.root: ب-ي-ن (b-y-n) - to be clear, to explain
grammar.reason: Describes what has happened - the truth became clear. Form V emphasizes clarity.
grammar.practical: From b-y-n (clear) we've seen before! Form V 'tabayyana' means 'to become clear, to be distinguished, to be evident'. The doubled 'y' and pattern ta-fa-'-a-la shows Form V - something becoming a certain state. So 'qad tabayyana' = 'it has indeed become clear'. What became clear? Coming next!

words.translation: the right course / the right guidance / the truth

grammar.root: ر-ش-د (r-sh-d) - to be rightly guided, to follow right path
grammar.reason: Subject of 'tabayyana'. WHAT became clear? The right guidance.
grammar.practical: From r-sh-d meaning right guidance and maturity. 'Rushd' is the right path, good guidance, proper conduct - the opposite of error. The 'u' shows it's the subject. 'Tabayyana ar-rushdu' = 'the right guidance has become clear'. This refers to Islam and truth - they're so clear and evident that anyone seeking sincerely can see them!

grammar.reason: Indicates the right path is distinguished FROM the wrong.
grammar.practical: 'Min' = 'from'. Here it shows separation or distinction. 'The right guidance [became clear] FROM...' meaning it's been separated from and distinguished from something else. What?

grammar.root: غ-ي-ي (gh-y-y) - to go astray, to err, to be misguided
grammar.reason: After preposition 'min'. What the right path is distinguished from.
grammar.practical: From gh-y-y meaning error, deviation, going astray. 'Ghayy' is misguidance, wrong path, falsehood - opposite of 'rushd'. The kasrah (i) is from 'min'. Complete phrase: 'qad tabayyana ar-rushdu min al-ghayy' = 'The right guidance has become clear from the error' or 'Truth is distinguished from falsehood'. The message: truth is so clear you don't need force - anyone can see it if they look honestly!

grammar.reason: Shows result: SINCE truth is clear, THEN whoever...
grammar.practical: 'Fa' (so/then) + 'man' (whoever) = 'fa-man' (so whoever). This introduces the consequence: SINCE the truth is clear, SO whoever does the following... The 'fa' shows logical connection. 'Man' is generic for anyone, everyone. What should they do?

grammar.reason: The condition after 'man'. Whoever does this action...
grammar.practical: From k-f-r (disbelieve) we've seen before. 'Yakfur' = 'he disbelieves/rejects'. In conditional 'man' clauses, the verb is jussive (no final vowel). So 'man yakfur' = 'whoever disbelieves' or 'whoever rejects'. Rejects what? Coming next!

words.translation: in Taghut / in false deities / in false objects of worship

grammar.root: ط-غ-ي (ṭ-gh-y) - to transgress, to exceed limits
grammar.reason: The 'bi' shows what is rejected. Disbelieve IN what?
grammar.practical: From ṭ-gh-y meaning to transgress or exceed limits. 'Ṭāghūt' means anything worshipped besides Allah - false gods, tyrants, Satan, idols - anything that transgresses its limits. It can be singular or plural in meaning. The 'bi' connects to the verb: 'yakfur BI...' = 'disbelieves IN'. So 'yakfur bi-ṭ-ṭāghūt' = 'rejects false deities/idols'. The first step to faith: reject all false gods!

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Present Tense Verb (Jussive)
grammar.reason: Second condition after 'man'. Whoever rejects falsehood AND believes...
grammar.practical: From a-m-n (believe). 'Yu'min' = 'he believes'. Combined with previous: 'man yakfur bi-ṭ-ṭāghūt wa yu'min...' = 'whoever rejects false deities AND believes...' Two conditions: (1) reject falsehood, (2) accept truth. Faith isn't just accepting - it's also rejecting what opposes truth!

grammar.reason: The 'bi' shows object of belief. Believes IN whom?
grammar.practical: Allah's blessed name with 'bi' and kasrah. 'Yu'min bi-llāh' = 'believes in Allah'. The complete condition: 'fa-man yakfur bi-ṭ-ṭāghūt wa yu'min bi-llāh' = 'So whoever rejects false gods and believes in Allah...' This is the essence of Tawhid: reject all false gods, accept only Allah! What happens to this person? Coming next!

words.translation: then indeed / then certainly / then has

grammar.reason: Shows the definite result of the condition. Then he has CERTAINLY...
grammar.practical: 'Fa' (then/so) + 'qad' (indeed) = double emphasis! This is the result: IF you reject falsehood and believe in Allah, THEN you have DEFINITELY... The combination 'fa-qad' makes the result emphatic and certain!

words.translation: he has grasped firmly / he has held fast

grammar.reason: The result of the condition. What has he done? Grasped firmly.
grammar.practical: From m-s-k meaning to hold or grasp. Form X 'istamsaka' means 'to seek to hold firmly, to grasp tightly, to cling to'. The pattern i-sta-f-a-la shows Form X - intensive seeking of an action. So 'fa-qad istamsaka' = 'then he has indeed grasped firmly' or 'he has held fast to'. Held fast to what? Coming next!

words.translation: to the handhold / to the handle

grammar.reason: The 'bi' shows what is grasped. Grasped WHAT?
grammar.practical: 'Urwah' means a handle, a loop, a handhold - something you grip firmly. Like the handle of a bucket or a rope loop. The 'bi' connects to the verb: 'istamsaka BI...' = 'grasped onto'. So 'istamsaka bi-l-'urwah' = 'grasped the handhold'. Beautiful metaphor! Faith in Allah is like grabbing a strong rope or handle. But not just any handhold...

words.translation: the most trustworthy / the firmest / the strongest

grammar.root: و-ث-ق (w-th-q) - to be firm, to trust, to be reliable
grammar.reason: Describes the handhold - which handhold? The firmest one!
grammar.practical: From w-th-q meaning firmness and trust. 'Wuthqā' is the feminine superlative: 'the firmest, most trustworthy, strongest'. So 'al-'urwatu-l-wuthqā' = 'the firmest handhold' or 'the most trustworthy handle'. Complete meaning: whoever rejects falsehood and believes in Allah has grabbed THE FIRMEST HANDHOLD - the strongest, most reliable connection possible! This is faith in Allah - an unbreakable bond!

grammar.reason: Describes the handhold - there is no break in it.
grammar.practical: 'Lā' = 'no' or 'there is no'. This describes the quality of this handhold. What doesn't it have?

grammar.root: ف-ص-م (f-ṣ-m) - to break, to sever, to snap
grammar.reason: What is negated. There is no breaking of it.
grammar.practical: From f-ṣ-m meaning to break or sever (specifically breaking without complete separation). Form VII 'infiṣām' is the verbal noun: 'breaking, severing, splitting'. The 'a' ending is from 'lā'. So 'lā infiṣāma' = 'there is no breaking' or 'no severing'. This handhold doesn't break!

grammar.reason: Specifies: no breaking belongs TO IT (the handhold).
grammar.practical: 'Li' (for/to) + 'hā' (it-feminine) = 'lahā' (for it, to it). Refers to the handhold ('urwah - feminine). So 'lā infiṣāma lahā' = 'there is no breaking for it' or 'it has no break'. Complete: 'istamsaka bi-l-'urwati-l-wuthqā lā infiṣāma lahā' = 'he grasped the firmest handhold, which has no break'. Faith in Allah alone is unbreakable! Everything else fails, but faith in Allah never breaks if you hold onto it!

grammar.reason: New sentence. Allah is the subject being described.
grammar.practical: 'Wa' + Allah's name with dammah. This begins the conclusion: 'And Allah...' What is Allah? Two attributes coming to complete the verse!

grammar.reason: First attribute of Allah. Predicate describing Him.
grammar.practical: From s-m-' meaning to hear. 'Samī'' is the intensive form: 'All-Hearing, Ever-Hearing, the One who hears everything'. The tanwīn (un) shows nominative case. Allah hears EVERYTHING - your declaration of faith, your prayers, your thoughts, every sound in creation. Nothing escapes His hearing!

grammar.reason: Second attribute of Allah. Second predicate.
grammar.practical: From '-l-m (know) we've seen throughout! ''Alīm' is intensive: 'All-Knowing, Ever-Knowing, the One who knows everything'. Allah knows your intentions, your heart, your struggles with faith. Complete: 'wa-llāhu samī'un 'alīm' = 'And Allah is All-Hearing, All-Knowing'. He hears your choice and knows your heart. These two names comfort the believer - Allah hears your prayers and knows your struggles!
